medical_history.chief_complaint: Acute onset of nausea, vomiting, and epigastric abdominal pain.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began last evening with acute nausea, vomiting, and severe epigastric abdominal pain. The patient reported increased alcohol intake over the past week, particularly using heavy liquor and beer the night prior. The abdominal pain was initially sharp but has decreased in intensity and is currently non-radiating. The patient also experienced visual disturbances (seeing spots), potentially a pre-aura for seizures. Symptoms improved with tolerable oral intake in the ED. Notably, this is the first occurrence of this type of episode.
medical_history.past_medical_history: History of epilepsy diagnosed at an unspecified age with the last seizure occurring several years ago; history of alcohol abuse; no past psychiatric illness.
medical_history.social_history: Denies history of delirium tremens (DTs) and has intermittent depressive symptoms. There is an indication of alcohol use, particularly heavy use on weekends, and poor appetite over the past eight months.
